sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) should be less than 2 times the normal value before urokinase is started and before instituting anticoagulants following the urokinase infusion
  • Pulmonary embolism: loading dose, 4400 international units/kg IV over 10 minutes (rate, 90 mL/hr), followed by a continuous infusion of 4400 international units/kg/hr IV for 12 hours (rate, 15 mL/hr), flush line at end of infusion; repeat dose as necessary

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy in children have not been established

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Pulmonary embolism
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Coronary artery bypass graft occlusion
  • Coronary artery thrombosis
  • Deep venous thrombosis
  • Empyema
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Pleural effusion
  • Prosthetic cardiac valve thrombosis
  • Venous catheter occlusion

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to urokinase
  • active internal bleeding
  • severe uncontrolled hypertension
  • recent intracranial or intraspinal surgery or trauma
  • intracranial neoplasm, arteriovenous malformation, or aneurysm
  • known bleeding diathesis
  • history of cerebrovascular accident

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• arterial and venous punctures should be minimized, especially at noncompressible sites
  • recent major surgery, e.g., coronary artery bypass graft, obstetrical delivery, organ biopsy
  • previous puncture of noncompressible vessels
  • cerebrovascular disease
  • recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary bleeding
  • recent trauma
  • hypertension: systolic BP greater than or equal to 175 mmHg and/or diastolic BP greater than or equal to 110 mmHg
  • high likelihood of left heart thrombus, e.g., mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation
  • acute pericarditis
  • subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • hemostatic defects
  • severe hepatic or renal dysfunction
  • pregnancy
  • diabetic hemorrhagic retinopathy or other hemorrhagic ophthalmic conditions
  • septic thrombophlebitis or occluded arteriovenous cannula at a seriously infected site
  • advanced age
  • patients currently receiving oral anticoagulants
  • known or suspected infection in the catheter during use for catheter clearance

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

1.title: Major
1.mono:
• Acenocoumarol (theoretical)
  • Alteplase, Recombinant (theoretical)
  • Anistreplase (theoretical)
  • Apixaban (theoretical)
  • Ardeparin (theoretical)
  • Argatroban (theoretical)
  • Bivalirudin (theoretical)
  • Certoparin (theoretical)
  • Dabigatran Etexilate (theoretical)
  • Dalteparin (theoretical)
  • Danaparoid (theoretical)
  • Desirudin (theoretical)
  • Edoxaban (theoretical)
  • Enoxaparin (theoretical)
  • Fondaparinux (theoretical)
  • Heparin (theoretical)
  • Lepirudin (theoretical)
  • Nadroparin (theoretical)
  • Parnaparin (theoretical)

  • Streptokinase (theoretical)
  • Tenecteplase (theoretical)
  • Tinzaparin (theoretical)
  • Warfarin (theoretical)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Hematologic:Decreased hematocrit level (37%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain, Embolization of vein, Ventricular arrhythmia, Reperfusion
  • Hematologic:Bleeding, Significant (2%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (less than 1%), Complication of infusion, Fever, chills, rigors, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, acidosis, back pain, nausea, vomiting

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Urokinase, an enzyme (protein), is a thrombolytic agent acquired from tissue culture of human neonatal kidney cells. It acts on the endogenous fibrinolytic system which converts plasminogen to enzyme plasmin. This enzyme is responsible for the degradation of fibrin clots, fibrinogen, and other plasma proteins.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • for IV infusion with a programmable infusion pump only
  • reconstitute vial with 5 mL Sterile Water for Injection without preservatives to a concentration of 50,000 units/mL immediately prior to use; do not use Bacteriostatic Water for Injection
  • roll and tilt vial to facilitate reconstitution; do not shake
  • further dilute with NS or D5W to the recommended final volume of 195 mL
  • may be terminally filtered (0.45-micron cellulose membrane filter or smaller)
  • do not administer other drugs in the same line as urokinase
  • (loading dose) administer at a rate of 90 mL/hr over 10 minutes
  • (continuous infusion) administer at a rate of 15 mL/hr for a period of 12 hr
  • flush with D5W or NS in amount equal to the tubing volume via the infusion pump at 15 mL/hr at the end of the infusion cycle

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• lung scan, restoration of blood flow
  • vital signs; frequently during and following infusion

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
THROMBOLYTICS
OVERDOSE: Symptoms are likely an extension of adverse effects. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Most common complication observed with thrombolytic therapy is hemorrhage, particularly from puncture sites; severe internal bleeding has occurred. Bleeding can occur at any site (eg, CNS, GI, GU, skin, mucosa). Other effects can include: nausea and vomiting, hallucinations, agitation, confusion, depression, bronchospasm, hyperthermia, chills, back or abdominal pain, leukocytosis, platelet activation, emboli, arterial occlusions, reperfusion dysrhythmias, cerebrovascular accidents, hypotension, hemopericardium, Guillain-Barre syndrome, renal dysfunction, hepatitis, and cutaneous or allergic reactions.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
THROMBOLYTICS
  • Decontamination: Not required.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Hemorrhage: Give fresh frozen plasma and/or cryoprecipitate, and packed RBCs for active bleeding.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl, blood products if bleeding, dopamine, or norepinephrine.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates.
  • Aminocaproic acid: Not documented as an antidote for streptokinase, but may be considered in an emergency. Dose - 16 to 20 mL (4 to 5 g) of Amicar(R) Injection in 250 mL of diluent, administered by infusion during the first hour of treatment, then a continuing infusion at a rate of 4 mL (1 g) per hour in 50 mL of diluent. Usually continued for about 8 hours or until the bleeding has been controlled.
  • Aprotinin: In several cases, aprotinin has been used to control bleeding following streptokinase administration.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs, CBC, renal function and hepatic enzymes in symptomatic patients. Monitor urine and stool for occult blood. Monitor hematocrit, hemoglobin, partial thromboplastin time, prothrombin time/INR, platelet count, and fibrinogen in patients with serious bleeding.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
THROMBOLYTICS
TOXICITY: Varies with agent. A minimum toxic dose has not been established.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Instruct patient to immediately report any spontaneous bleeding or cardiovascular effects such as chest pain and arrhythmias.
